Hey there!
I‚Äôm a 6th-year PhD Candidate in Economics at the University of Zurich.
My main field of interest is Empirical Industrial Organization; in particular, I‚Äôm working on the economics of strategic information disclosure. In my job market paper, I estimate a structural model of Bayesian Persuasion seeking to understand the design of the Airbnb customer rating system. My results reveal how the platform benefits from almost every apartment having a 5-star rating and its consequences relative to a full-information alternative.
My principal supervisor is Greg Crawford.
I am on the academic job market 2022/2023 and available for interviews!

content:
Abstract Creating trust between strangers is the backbone of the sharing-economy business model. In this context, consumer ratings are arguably the most important source of information on trustworthiness and quality. However, we observe extremely little variation (and hence information) in star ratings on major platforms. In this paper, I study the Airbnb rating system in a Bayesian persuasion framework (Kamenica and Gentzkow, 2011) by treating ratings as signals for unobserved quality. With the design of the rating system, the platform chooses an information structure to maximize the share of customers who choose the platform over outside options and thus their commissions. This approach reveals the importance of ratings for the functioning of the platform but also Airbnb‚Äôs incentives to design a rating system that encourages imperfect information transmission on quality. I set up a numerically solvable demand model of the short-term accommodation market around this Bayesian persuasion problem and its interplay with the platform‚Äôs pricing decision and hosts‚Äô decision to join the platform and exert costly effort to improve their quality. I exploit variation in the rating distribution and market conditions across 56 major travel destinations in the United States over the years 2018 and 2019 to structurally estimate this model and back out the distribution of unobserved quality. Counterfactual exercises suggest that (i) the platform would break down without a rating system, and (ii) Airbnb‚Äôs strategic rating system design led to a consumer welfare loss of USD288M and a redistribution of profits form high to medium quality hosts of almost USD750M compared to fully revealing ratings in the markets and period studied.
Draft coming soon.

This note investigates, in part theoretically and in part computationally, when and how the order of move matters in a Conversational War of Attrition (Meyer-ter-Vehn, Smith, and Bognar, 2017). Switching the first mover flips the outcome of the debate for certain type-realizations and triggers two potentially opposing forces on jurors‚Äô ex-ante expected costs. In the finite-horizon version of the game, there is a second-to-last-mover advantage that prevails if the jurors‚Äô bias dominates their impatience, and a first-mover-advantage that prevails if impatience dominates bias. In the infinite-horizon version, there is an unambiguous first-mover-advantage. These mechanisms are reminiscent of the seminal Rubinstein (1982) sequential bargaining game.
Draft available upon request.

summary: Clinical research should conform to high standards of ethical and scientific integrity, given that human lives are at stake. However, economic incentives can generate conflicts of interest for investigators, who may be inclined to withhold unfavorable results or even tamper with data in order to achieve desired outcomes. To shed light on the integrity of clinical trial results, this paper systematically analyzes the distribution of P values of primary outcomes for phase II and phase III drug trials reported to the ClinicalTrials.gov registry. First, we detect no bunching of results just above the classical 5% threshold for statistical significance. Second, a density-discontinuity test reveals an upward jump at the 5% threshold for phase III results by small industry sponsors. Third, we document a larger fraction of significant results in phase III compared to phase II. Linking trials across phases, we find that early favorable results increase the likelihood of continuing into the next phase. Once we take into account this selective continuation, we can explain almost completely the excess of significant results in phase III for trials conducted by large industry sponsors. For small industry sponsors, instead, part of the excess remains unexplained.
title: P-hacking in clinical trials and how incentives shape the distribution of results across phases
